sessions.title: Introduction to commercetools Platform
sessions.overview: This session introduces commercetools concepts, capabilities, and key resources. You will set up projects and explore essential tools like the Merchant Center.

keyDecisions.title: Public Beta Features
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving is evaluating a new Public Beta Feature (Multiple Customer Group Assignment) for its loyalty campaign.

options.text: Evaluate in staging: Test thoroughly before production.
options.feedback: While rigorous staging testing lowers risk, it might delay benefits. Consider a gradual production rollout for a quicker market response.

options.text: Start gradually in production: Roll out with limited scope and close monitoring.
options.feedback: Correct. This approach balances speed and risk, gathering timely feedback and allowing agile adjustments.

options.text: Wait for GA: Delay until the feature is generally available.
options.feedback: Although waiting for GA ensures stability, it may slow innovation. A gradual rollout with controlled monitoring typically offers a better balance.

keyDecisions.title: Limits
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving is nearing the 10,000-category limit due to heavy use of product categories. How should they increase the limit?

options.text: Submit a support request to boost the limit.
options.feedback: Correct. Officially raising the limit aligns with best practices and ensures scalability without complicating your data structure.

options.text: Reorganize into subcategories or adjust attributes.
options.feedback: While this might temporarily ease the strain, it doesn't actually expand capacity and may overcomplicate your structure.

options.text: Use custom fields to simulate extra categories.
options.feedback: A workaround at best; it doesn’t truly increase the limit. Pursuing an official limit increase is advisable.

keyDecisions.title: Organization & Project Setup
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving must determine the optimal DEV and PROD setup.

options.text: Same organization, separate projects.
options.feedback: Central management is convenient but may not provide enough production isolation.

options.text: Isolate PROD in its own organization.
options.feedback: Correct. Separating PROD into its own organization enhances security and risk mitigation per best practices.

options.text: Single project; publish products & other data only when production-ready.
options.feedback: This approach blurs DEV/PROD boundaries, increasing risks. Isolation offers better operational safety.

sessions.title: Product Modeling Basics
sessions.overview: This session covers setting up the commercetools project, creating a customer in Merchant Center, and the basics of product modeling: product types, attributes, and variants.

keyDecisions.title: Product Modeling
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving launches the 'Maya Pillow Cover' available in various colors and materials.

options.text: Use multiple product variants: Manage variants as per different colors/materials efficiently within a single product.
options.feedback: Correct: Using product variants streamlines management by grouping different attributes under one product, ensuring consistency and efficient operations.

options.text: Separate Products: Create standalone products for clear individual SEO and marketing.
options.feedback: Although separate products might boost SEO, they lead to redundancy and complicate inventory management. Consider using product variants for a cohesive strategy if it stays withing the limits.

options.text: Hybrid Approach: Create Variants by color in one product and create another separat product with variants by material to optimize discoverability.
options.feedback: Could be overcomplicated: While hybrid strategies sound flexible, they might add unnecessary complexity. A unified product variant approach is usually recommended within the limits or consider creating separate products

keyDecisions.title: Product Configuration
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving needs rich, multilingual product specifications and descriptions in different locales.

options.text: Use LocalizedText to provide clear, detailed, and localized product descriptions.
options.feedback: Correct: LocalizedText fields deliver the needed detail in multiple languages, making product descriptions clear even if they aren’t optimized for filtering.

options.text: Use Multilingual Text Field attributes to offer language-specific content.
options.feedback: Consider this: While multilingual fields  might work, using dedicated LocalizedText ensures consistency and better integration for detailed content.

options.text: Structured Filterable Attributes: Focus on attributes optimized for filtering rather than detailed description.
options.feedback: Not optimal: Filterable attributes are great for search but fall short on conveying the full descriptive detail in different locales needed for rich product content.

keyDecisions.title: Choosing the Correct Identifier
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving must decide which identifier to use for stable integrations and efficient querying.

options.text: Use IDs which are automatically generated for each resource
options.feedback: Avoid this: System-generated IDs are not designed for external integrations. Rely on them only for internal tracking.

options.text: Use Key to have meaningful, readable to have stable code integrations.
options.feedback: Correct: The key is the recommended identifier for stable external references and integrations due to its clarity and adaptability.

options.text: Use SKU
options.feedback: Not the best choice: While SKU is vital for stock management, it isn’t suited as a primary code reference. Use it only for inventory purposes.

options.text: Use Slug to have SEO-friendly URLs and SEO
options.feedback: Not ideal: Slugs are perfect for user-friendly URLs for products / categories only, not for stable integration.

description.content: AllForFoodies plans to launch online cooking classes using an integrated product model.
commercetools acts as a PIM and Order Management System.
Create a product model using a product type ‘Online Offering’ and associated variants.
Draft your solution in the Notes field with your team.

sessions.title: Advanced Product Modeling
sessions.overview: This session dives deeper into product modeling strategies and effective promotion tactics to enhance commerce performance.

keyDecisions.title: Dynamic Recommendations Strategy
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving plans dynamic recommendations between products like 'Edgar Armchair' and 'Silky Pillow Cover'. Which strategy do you prefer?

options.text: Product Reference Attributes: Direct, explicit links for curation.
options.feedback: Correct. This approach ensures precise, manual curation. Consider this optimal method for reliable recommendations.

options.text: Attribute-based Lookup: Store the recommended SKU/ID in a custom field and fetch via API.
options.feedback: Not ideal. Think about how explicit linking minimizes extra API calls and inconsistency. Consider the recommended reference attributes instead.

options.text: Category Matching: Use same-category filtering for dynamic recommendations.
options.feedback: Less precise. Reflect on how using categories alone might retrieve unrelated products. Consider explicit product references for higher accuracy.

keyDecisions.title: Seasonal Category Management
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving frequently updates its seasonal collections. Which category management approach best suits this need?

options.text: Season-based Parent Categories: Use top-level seasonal categories (e.g., Summer, Winter).
options.feedback: Correct. This straightforward method provides clarity. Consider this optimal approach for managing seasonal changes.

options.text: Attribute-based Dynamic Categories: Auto-assign products using seasonal attributes.
options.feedback: Automated but less controlled. Think about the benefits of clear, top-level seasonal categories instead.

options.text: Combined Hierarchy and Attributes: Mix static categories for SEO with dynamic attributes.
options.feedback: This adds complexity. Reflect on how a simpler season-based approach might work better.

keyDecisions.title: Product Bundling
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving offers multiple products bundled with discounted prices to boost sales, but bundling isn’t natively supported. How should these be modeled?

options.text: Use Reference Attributes: Link items via reference attributes.
options.feedback: Correct. This method provides flexible, scalable linking between products. Consider this approach as the best option.

options.text: Implement Cart-Level Logic: Add bundled items as a gift line item or apply discount logic at the cart level.
options.feedback: Not ideal. Cart-level logic may introduce complexity with extra rules and may be less consistent than explicit references.

options.text: Same-Category Discounting: Configure products in the same category and use cart discounts for items within that category.
options.feedback: Less precise. Reflect on how this approach may rely too much on category membership, which can lead to less targeted recommendations. Consider explicit linking instead.

sessions.title: Stores and Channels
sessions.overview: This session focuses on pricing strategies, product selections, supply channel configuration, and tailoring product offerings for different regions.

keyDecisions.title: Regional Pricing Strategy
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving is expanding in APAC—launching in Australia (AUD), Japan (JPY), and Singapore (SGD). Which pricing channel strategy best fits these diverse markets?

options.text: Single Channel, Multiple Currencies: Use one pricing channel (e.g., apac-price-channel) and configure it with multiple currency prices (e.g., apac-price-channel + AUD / JPY / SGD ).
options.feedback: While a single channel simplifies management, it may not provide sufficient control for market-specific pricing nuances. Consider a method that allows country-level differentiation.

options.text: Single Channel with Price per Country: Use one regional pricing channel (e.g., apac-price-channel) and define distinct prices for each country (e.g., set a specific AUD price for Australia, JPY for Japan, and SGD for Singapore).
options.feedback: Correct. This approach offers clear, country-specific control within a single channel, ensuring that each market’s pricing is tailored appropriately. Consider this optimal for handling diverse currencies and regional pricing dynamics.

options.text: Mixed (Hybrid): Combine a common channel with fallback prices for most markets, plus dedicated channels for selected regions (e.g., Australia could have a dedicated channel with both AUD and USD prices).
options.feedback: This strategy introduces extra complexity and might be hard to manage. Reflect on how a single channel with country-specific pricing usually provides the right balance of simplicity and control.

keyDecisions.title: Product Selections
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving manages exclusive regional product availability (e.g., for EU, APAC, UA). Which strategy best delineates regional catalogs?

options.text: Inclusion-based Selections: Explicitly define which products are available per region.
options.feedback: Correct. This approach clearly outlines product availability for each region. Consider this the most straightforward method.

options.text: Exclusion-based Selections: Offer global availability with specific regional exclusions.
options.feedback: Not ideal. Reflect on how exclusions can be ambiguous, leading to inconsistencies. Consider explicit inclusion instead.

options.text: Combined Inclusion-Exclusion: Global core catalog with explicit regional exclusions.
options.feedback: Overly complex. Think about the benefits of a simple, clear inclusion-based approach for predictable regional availability.

keyDecisions.title: Supply Channel Configuration
keyDecisions.scenario: For example, EcoLiving sources products from different warehouses to serve the APAC market. How should the supply channel be configured for accurate inventory tracking?

options.text: Dedicated Supply Channel per Warehouse: Assign a specific channel for each warehouse.
options.feedback: Correct. This method provides clear and direct tracking for each warehouse. Consider this approach for precise inventory management.

options.text: Centralized Supply Channel: Use a single channel for all warehouses with fallback logic.
options.feedback: Not ideal. Think about how a centralized channel can blur distinctions between warehouses, reducing tracking accuracy.

options.text: Dynamic Supply Mapping: Auto-map products to warehouses using custom logic.
options.feedback: Reflect on how dynamic mapping might introduce complexity & need for custom logic to map to nearest warehouse. Consider the clarity of dedicated channels.

keyDecisions.title: Product Tailoring for Regional Stores
keyDecisions.scenario: EcoLiving wants products tailored differently in each regional store. How can tailored content be best achieved?

options.text: Same Product, Tailored Presentation: Use built-in product tailoring to adjust name, description, and images per region.
options.feedback: Correct. This approach leverages a single product with region-specific presentation, ensuring consistency and efficiency. Consider this optimal for maintaining centralized data with localized appeal.

options.text: Create Separate Products: Develop distinct products per region and assign them using product selections.
options.feedback: Not ideal. Think about how creating separate products increases duplication and complexity. Reflect on the benefits of tailoring a single product.

options.text: Attribute-Based Tailoring: Use product attributes for regional variations and display only relevant ones.
options.feedback: Less effective. Reflect on how this method might not provide the full customization needed. Consider the tailored presentation of a single product for better control.
